## Conservation & rarity context

-   IUCN: NA; Florida: Somewhat rare native
-   **Rarity note:** Distributed in most of Florida except for the South Florida region and is less urban tolerant than other ant species.

## Natural history notes

The chestnut carpenter ant (Camponotus castaneus) forms moderately sized colonies and occurs throughout the eastern United States. These ants are omnivorous and often collect dead insects as part of their diet. Several related Camponotus species are found in Florida, but the chestnut carpenter ant is considered one of the less commonly encountered.
